title: 107_hr1623
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as historically women's public college or university, historic building or structure, and Secretary. SEC. 3. Preservation and restoration grants for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. The Secretary shall award grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings on their campuses. Grants will be funded through the National Historic Preservation Act for fiscal years 2002-2006. Grantees must agree not to alter the property without the Secretary's approval. The Secretary awards grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings on their campuses. Grantees must agree not to alter the property without the Secretary's approval and provide reasonable public access for interpretive and educational purposes. Funds may be obligated for buildings or structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places, National Historic Landmarks, or within designated historic districts, with a matching requirement from non-Federal funds. The Secretary awards grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings on their campuses. Grantees must agree to provide activities under the grant funded by non-Federal sources, with the Secretary providing 50% of the costs. In-kind contributions can be used for the non-Federal share of costs. Funding provisions state that not more than $16,000,000 for each fiscal year 2002 through 2006 may be made available under this section. For fiscal year 2002, $2,000,000 is available for grants under subsection (a) for specific universities including Mississippi University for Women, Georgia College and State University, University of North Carolina, Winthrop University, University of Montevallo, and Texas Woman's University. For fiscal year 2002, specific universities like University of Montevallo in Alabama, Texas Woman's University in Texas, University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma in Oklahoma, and Wesleyan College in Georgia may receive reduced funding if less than $16,000,000 is available. Funds for fiscal years 2003-2006 will be distributed by the Secretary. The Secretary will distribute funds for fiscal years 2003-2006 to eligible grantees on a uniform basis. The Secretary will also promulgate necessary regulations to implement this Act.
